body:
Thanks for raising the issue @ParthivNaresh! 

This is related to https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/670

Would appreciate if you look into this. We should either fix it if possible, or raise an error.

issue.title: TimeSeries support for datetime frequency not of unit 1

labels.name: spike
labels.description: To generate additional issues and kick off a sprint.

repository.name: evalml
repository.description: EvalML is an AutoML library written in python.

issue.body:
Currently sktime has trouble with predicting datetime values in datasets that have a frequency other than unit 1.
For example, if the data is separated by datetime values at the granularity level of 1 second, 1 minute, 1 day, or 1 month, there is no issue.
However with frequencies of 10 minutes, 2 hours, or 3 months, the `ForecastingHorizon` within sktime runs into issues.
A [bug has been filed with sktime](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/805) for more context.

We should have an in-house check for time series data that is passed in with a frequency that falls under this issue, with the intention that the minimum frequency should be used for the data. i.e. 10 minute intervals should be reduced to 1 minute intervals.

body: @ParthivNaresh could you confirm if this is still an issue with the latest code on `main` with the changes from #873?

@mloning Sorry for the late response, I'm still seeing this error with `sktime==0.7.0`.

Using `1D` as the `freq`:
```
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
from sktime.forecasting.arima import AutoARIMA
from sktime.forecasting.base import ForecastingHorizon

time_index = pd.date_range("January 1, 2021", periods=8, freq='1D')
X = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randint(0, 4, 24).reshape(8,3), columns=["First", "Second", "Third"], 
                 index=time_index)
y = pd.Series([1, 3, 2, 4, 5, 2, 3, 1], index=time_index)

fh_ = ForecastingHorizon(X.index[5:], is_relative=False)

a_clf = AutoARIMA(start_p=2, start_q=2, max_p=5, max_q=5)
clf = a_clf.fit(X=X[:5], y=y[:5])
y_pred_sk = clf.predict(fh=fh_, X=X[5:])

y_pred_sk
============================================================================

2021-01-06    3.778834
2021-01-07    7.151245
2021-01-08    5.387020
dtype: float64
```

Using `2D` as the `freq`:
```
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
from sktime.forecasting.arima import AutoARIMA
from sktime.forecasting.base import ForecastingHorizon

time_index = pd.date_range("January 1, 2021", periods=8, freq='2D')
X = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randint(0, 4, 24).reshape(8,3), columns=["First", "Second", "Third"], 
                 index=time_index)
y = pd.Series([1, 3, 2, 4, 5, 2, 3, 1], index=time_index)

fh_ = ForecastingHorizon(X.index[5:], is_relative=False)

a_clf = AutoARIMA(start_p=2, start_q=2, max_p=5, max_q=5)
clf = a_clf.fit(X=X[:5], y=y[:5])
y_pred_sk = clf.predict(fh=fh_, X=X[5:])

y_pred_sk
============================================================================

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-37-8ef2c961eff7> in <module>
      3 a_clf = AutoARIMA(start_p=2, start_q=2, max_p=5, max_q=5)
      4 clf = a_clf.fit(X=X[:5], y=y[:5])
----> 5 y_pred_sk = clf.predict(fh=fh_, X=X[5:])

~/miniconda3/envs/main/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sktime/forecasting/base/_base.py in predict(self, fh, X, return_pred_int, alpha)
    156         # alpha = check_alpha(alpha)
    157 
--> 158         return self._predict(self.fh, X, return_pred_int=return_pred_int, alpha=alpha)
    159 
    160     def fit_predict(

~/miniconda3/envs/main/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sktime/forecasting/base/adapters/_pmdarima.py in _predict(self, fh, X, return_pred_int, alpha)
     56         # all values are out-of-sample
     57         if fh.is_all_out_of_sample(self.cutoff):
---> 58             return self._predict_fixed_cutoff(fh_oos, **kwargs)
     59 
     60         # all values are in-sample

~/miniconda3/envs/main/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sktime/forecasting/base/adapters/_pmdarima.py in _predict_fixed_cutoff(self, fh, X, return_pred_int, alpha)
    104         # make prediction
    105         n_periods = int(fh.to_relative(self.cutoff)[-1])
--> 106         result = self._forecaster.predict(
    107             n_periods=n_periods,
    108             X=X,

~/miniconda3/envs/main/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pmdarima/utils/metaestimators.py in <lambda>(*args, **kwargs)
     51 
     52         # lambda, but not partial, allows help() to work with update_wrapper
---> 53         out = (lambda *args, **kwargs: self.fn(obj, *args, **kwargs))
     54         # update the docstring of the returned function
     55         update_wrapper(out, self.fn)

~/miniconda3/envs/main/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pmdarima/arima/auto.py in predict(self, n_periods, X, return_conf_int, alpha, **kwargs)
    255         # Temporary shim until we remove `exogenous` support completely
    256         X, _ = pm_compat.get_X(X, **kwargs)
--> 257         return self.model_.predict(
    258             n_periods=n_periods,
    259             X=X,

~/miniconda3/envs/main/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pmdarima/arima/arima.py in predict(self, n_periods, X, return_conf_int, alpha, **kwargs)
    668         X = self._check_exog(X)  # type: np.ndarray
    669         if X is not None and X.shape[0] != n_periods:
--> 670             raise ValueError('X array dims (n_rows) != n_periods')
    671 
    672         # f = self.arima_res_.forecast(steps=n_periods, exog=X)

ValueError: X array dims (n_rows) != n_periods
```

@mloning I believe the issue persists if `is_relative` is set to `True` and feature values are passed to the `fit` and `predict`. Every other use case works, `is_relative=False, no features passed`, `is_relative=False, features passed`, and `is_relative=True, no features passed` work without any issue for various frequency intervals.
Thanks @ParthivNaresh - this is something we need to further investigate then!

Here is the root cause of this bug:
```
index = pd.period_range("January 1, 2021", periods=3, freq='2D')
index - index[0]

Index([<0 * Days>, <4 * Days>, <8 * Days>], dtype='object')

[val - index[0] for val in index]

[<0 * Days>, <2 * Days>, <4 * Days>]
```
Can somebody understand WTF is going on here???

issue.title: [BUG] `ForecastingHorizon.to_relative` wrongly converts `pd.index` with frequencies that are base frequency multiples to `int`s

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
<!--
A clear and concise description of what the bug is.
-->
`ForecastHorizon.to_relative` is wrong when using pandas date ranges with frequencies that are multiples of base frequencies (e.g "2H", "30T", "10D").
I believe the cause is the function `_coerce_duration_to_int`.

Seems to be related to #1435 and #1876 (sorry if this is a duplicate)

**To Reproduce**
<!--
Add a Minimal, Complete, and Verifiable example (for more details, see e.g. https://stackoverflow.com/help/mcve

If the code is too long, feel free to put it in a public gist and link it in the issue: https://gist.github.com
-->

```python
import pandas as pd
from sktime.forecasting.base import ForecastingHorizon

freq = '2H'
t = pd.date_range(start='2021-01-01', freq=freq, periods=5)
fh_abs = ForecastingHorizon(t, is_relative=False)
fh_rel = fh_abs.to_relative(cutoff=t.min())
print(fh_rel)
```
Output:
```
ForecastingHorizon([0, 4, 8, 12, 16], dtype='int64', is_relative=True)
```

**Expected behavior**
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen.
-->
Output should be:
```
ForecastingHorizon([0, 1, 2, 3, 4], dtype='int64', is_relative=True)
```
no matter what `freq` is.


To see this bug in action, consider the following example of using a NaiveForecaster to predict a perfectly periodic time series:
```python
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from sktime.forecasting.base import ForecastingHorizon
from sktime.forecasting.model_selection import temporal_train_test_split
from sktime.forecasting.naive import NaiveForecaster

sp = 5  # period
n = sp * 2  # number of samples

y = pd.Series(
    index=pd.date_range(start='2021-01-01', freq='2H', periods=n),
    data=np.mod(np.arange(n), sp),
)

y_train, y_test = temporal_train_test_split(y, test_size=sp)
fh = ForecastingHorizon(y_test.index, is_relative=False)
forecaster = NaiveForecaster(strategy="last", sp=sp)
forecaster.fit(y_train)
y_pred = forecaster.predict(fh)
print(y_test, y_pred, np.abs(y_pred - y_test).max(), sep='\n\n')
```

Output:
```
2021-01-01 10:00:00    0
2021-01-01 12:00:00    1
2021-01-01 14:00:00    2
2021-01-01 16:00:00    3
2021-01-01 18:00:00    4
Freq: 2H, dtype: int64

2021-01-01 10:00:00    3.0
2021-01-01 12:00:00    2.0
2021-01-01 14:00:00    1.0
2021-01-01 16:00:00    0.0
2021-01-01 18:00:00    4.0
dtype: float64

3.0
```
**Versions**
<details>

<!--
Please run the following code snippet and paste the output here:
 
from sktime import show_versions; show_versions()
-->
Python 3.9.5 (default, May 18 2021, 12:31:01) 
Type 'copyright', 'credits' or 'license' for more information
IPython 8.0.1 -- An enhanced Interactive Python. Type '?' for help.
PyDev console: using IPython 8.0.1
System:
    python: 3.9.5 (default, May 18 2021, 12:31:01)  [Clang 10.0.0 ]
executable: /Users/tomshlomo/miniconda3/envs/playground-395/bin/python
   machine: macOS-10.15.7-x86_64-i386-64bit
Python dependencies:
          pip: 21.1.1
   setuptools: 52.0.0.post20210125
      sklearn: 1.0.2
       sktime: 0.9.0
  statsmodels: 0.13.1
        numpy: 1.20.2
        scipy: 1.6.2
       Cython: 0.29.26
       pandas: 1.2.4
   matplotlib: 3.3.4
       joblib: 1.0.1
        numba: 0.54.1
     pmdarima: None
      tsfresh: 0.17.0
</details>

<!-- Thanks for contributing! -->

body:
>Can somebody understand [blank] is going on here???

The root cause seems to be a `pandas` bug, as identified in #1935.

issue.title: [BUG] Fix a bug in PeriodIndex arithmetic

labels.name: bugfix
labels.description: Fixes a known bug or removes unintended behavior

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->

Fixes https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/805. Fixes https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1935. Fixes https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1435. Fixes https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1876.

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->

Convert `PeriodIndex` `absolute` to `DatetimeIndex`, as well as `cutoff` and `start` `Period` to `Timestamp` before taking the difference between the two.

This circumvents the following bug in pandas:
```
periods = pd.period_range(start="2021-01-01", periods=3, freq="2H")
periods - periods[0]
Out: Index([<0 * Hours>, <4 * Hours>, <8 * Hours>], dtype = 'object')
[v - periods[0] for v in periods]
Out: Index([<0 * Hours>, <2 * Hours>, <4 * Hours>], dtype='object')
```

Bug report scripts were added as explicit test cases and should be replaced later with lightweight unit tests.

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
-->

No.

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

<!-- This section is particularly useful if you have a pull request that is still in development. You can guide the reviews to focus on the parts that are ready for their comments. We suggest using bullets (indicated by * or -) and filled checkboxes [x] here -->

#### Any other comments?
<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering, convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.
-->

#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [X] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [ ] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [X] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.

<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->

body: With this little change https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/1981 both of the examples in https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/805#issuecomment-891848228 run as expected.

Now it makes sense:
```
index = pd.period_range("January 1, 2021", periods=3, freq='2D').to_timestamp()
print(index - index[0])
print([val - index[0] for val in index])

TimedeltaIndex(['0 days', '2 days', '4 days'], dtype='timedelta64[ns]', freq=None)
[Timedelta('0 days 00:00:00'), Timedelta('2 days 00:00:00'), Timedelta('4 days 00:00:00')]
```
yes, but a lot of other failures pop up... ☹️
